awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Data-driven dynamic adaptive optimization for next generation power system operation
awd_abstract_narration:
The objective of this Faculty Early Career Development Program (CAREER) project is to create a set of novel optimization models and algorithms for the operation of future electric power systems. The approach is to (1) develop efficient and robust algorithms for optimizing power flow and power network topology, which will be significantly faster, more accurate, and more scalable than the state-of-the-art approaches; (2) develop new techniques for harnessing large amount of data for modeling uncertainties in power system; (3) develop decision making algorithms for the real-time operation of power systems with substantial renewable, demand response, and distributed generation resources. The intellectual merits of the project lie in (1) the development of new insights and understanding of some key mathematical structures of a broad class of hard optimization problems involving networks, which are intrinsic to optimal power flow, network topology control, and dynamic decision making, and (2) leveraging these mathematical understanding to design rigorous and efficient algorithms for the mentioned problems. If successful, this research will not only provide transformative technologies for the operations of power grid, but will also strengthen intellectual ties between power engineering and industrial & operations engineering.
 
The project will directly benefit the society at large by creating the next generation of operational tools to manage the future power grids,  to help reduce power system operational cost, and to increase power system reliability and flexibility. The methodological contributions of the project will provide new tools for applications beyond electric power systems, such as for the operation of water and natural-gas networks and coordination of interconnected energy systems. The PI will actively pursue opportunities to bring power industry, academia, government, and national labs together to form synergistic discussions and collaborations on developing analytical methods for electric energy systems. The PI will also develop new education curriculum and outreach activities to contribute to the development of a new generation of multidisciplinary workforce for the nation's infrastructure industry.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Electric power systems in the U.S. are experiencing rapid changes driven by renewable energy integration, retirement of coal power plants, adoption of smart grid technologies, especially demand side management, and increasing electrification of transportation and heating. To continue and accelerate these structural changes of the physical power grid, the mathematical foundations for operating and planning future power grids must also change.

This NSF CAREER project takes a systemic approach to tackle two sources of challenges in developing new mathematical optimization methodologies for grid operation and planning. One source of challenge is the increasing uncertainty in the power generation and demand, coming from renewable resources and new types of demand. Such uncertainty must be dealt with proactively to ensure power system reliability. The other source is the highly nonconvex structure of power flows and discrete decisions that make it challenging to optimally schedule large-scale power grid.

To tackle the first challenge, the project has developed a suite of new models for optimization under uncertainty, including two-stage robust optimization for economic dispatch of a renewable-rich power system, multi-stage stochastic and distributionally robust optimization models for hydro-power plants scheduling and long-term planning. The project also produces new algorithms and theoretical analysis of the computational complexity of the new algorithms, resolving some open questions in the mathematical foundations of dynamic optimization.

To tackle the second challenge, the project has developed a new generation of computation methods for solving large-scale optimal power flow problems, including strong convex relaxations that are both fast to solve and produce very strong bounds to certify global optimality. The project also developed new first-order algorithms for solving nonconvex, nonsmooth optimization problems, which can be applied to a broad range of problems in power grid optimization.

In addition to the above intellectual contributions, the PI has the vision to bridge multiple disciplines and academia and industry through outreach. In particular, the PI has initiated and organized a series of four annual workshops on power system optimization and control. These workshops brought together academic researchers from OR, power engineering, control, economics, and computer science, leading utility companies and power system operators, and regulators. The workshop attracted hundreds of participants throughout the world, especially early-career researchers and students. It is extremely satisfying to learn that many of the students decided to pursue power engineering and OR after attending the workshops.

The PI has also trained several PhD students in OR and power engineering, thanks to the support of this grant.
